bioghist.p: A pediatrician and virologist trained at the University of Rochester and Harvard Medical School, Daniel Carleton Gajdusek became interested in epidemiological issues in "exotic and isolated populations" early in the 1950s, and while working as a visiting investigator at the Walter and Eliza Institute of Medical Research in Melbourne he had his first introduction to a neurological disorder, kuru, that was endemic among the Neolithic Fore of New Guinea. In an exemplary study, Gajudusek determined that kuru was not hereditary, as previously supposed, but was an infectious disease transmitted through the ritualistic consumption of the brains of deceased relatives. He was recognized for his achievements with the 1976 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional and personal papers of Carlton Gajdusek. Materials include: incoming and outgoing work-related correspondence, contracts, financial records, and performance appraisals; research materials related to the Middle Eastern Serum Study; family correspondence with his mother, Ottilia Mahtil Dobrosky Gajdusek (1893-1966), brother, Robert Elemer Gajdusek (b. 1925) and his children and grandchildren; school records of his adoptive children; biographical sketches of correspondents; and CVs and supporting materials. The collection also includes journals from 1937-1940 and 1951-1998 documenting his medical and epidemiological research (especially that on Kuru), pediatric studies, and human and population genetics work in Africa, Australia, Colombia, Guam, Indonesia, Libya, Melanesia, New Guinea, New Hebrides, Pacific Islands, Paraguay, Soviet Union, and the Western Caroline Islands; annotated typescripts and photocopies of the journals.
